The attention of English and American lacrosse enthusiasts
will be centered upon Homewood Field tomorrow, when the combined lacrosse teams of Oxford and Cambridge, fresh from their recent victories over the championship Lehigh team and the Penn
State stickmen, will meet the powerful twelve representing Johns
Hopkins University. Intense interest has been indicated by a large
advance sale of tickets, and lacrosse fans from Washington, Philadelphia, Annapolis and other nearby points will probably be a part
of the record crowd which is expected to be on hand when the referee's whistle announces the commencement of hostilities.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 7, 1922

2

The Johns Hopkins News-Letter

HOPKINS DISTINGUISHED
SCIENTISTS

FOUNDED 1897.

Dr. Ira Remsen was born in
New York City, February 10, 1846.
He received the degree of A. B. in
1865 from the College of the City
of New York. This was followed
by an M. D. at Columbia in '67.
Dr. Remsen later received degrees
of LL. D. at a number of the lead-.
ing universities of North America,
including Yale, Harvard, Toronto,
Princeton, etc. From 1872 to 1876
he was professor at Williams College. From that date until 1913
Dr. Remsen was Professor of
Chemistry at Johns Hopkins. In
1901 he was elected President of
the University and he held that office until his resignation in 1913.
He belonged to practically all the
foremost chemical and scientific societies in this country and abroad,
and has written a number of books
which have added greatly to the
literature upon chemistry. Among
them are "The Principles of Theoretical Chemistry," "The Elements
of Chemistry," "Inorganic Chemistry," and "Chemical Experiments." These books had a vast
influence in the study of the science

WE HAVE WITH US
Tomorrow we will have as our guests a group of selected athletes, representing the two oldest universities in the world.
Most of them are obtaining their first impression of America on
this trip. Thus far, they have invaded the lacrosse field of three universities and have come away with the victor's end of the spoils. We
have reason to believe that things will not go so easily with them out
at Homewood Field tomorrow. The game should be hotly contested throughout and it is therefore essential that both rooters and
players make an especial effort to display good sportsmanship.
The fact that an ex-Hopkins student and player is among the
visitors should serve as an incentive to us to "do him proud".
This international contest, more than all of the other games
combined, will carry with it a great amount of advertising and comment concerning Johns Hopkins.
We can afford to do nothing else than put our best foot forward.
Let's show the visitors from the old world what clean winners—or
what good losers we are.

WANTED
The cheering at the games last Saturday, although good, lacked
the force of supervised effort. The scattered groups of rooters were
enthusiastic and generous with their applause, but the result was
weak and would have been far more pleasing had their efforts been
concentrated.
Through the endeavors of the Sigma Chi Beta Honorary Society, last year, spring sport cheer-leaders were provided. Their
services, with that of the band, served to produce a much smootherrunning rooting section.
Inasmuch as our collection of yell-directors will be sadly depleted by the opening of next term, these spring games seem to offer
an excellent opportunity for the schooling of the new aspirants in
the art of writhing and twisting.
The position of Head Cheer Leader is one offering splendid occasions for an injection of personality. While at first consideration
the office may not appear as exalted a one as that of fullback on
the
football team or star, twirler on the nine, it should be
remembered
that it can be made what its holder wills.
Cheer Leader Mike Curley will be remembered long after
most
of the "star twirlers" of his institution have faded into the
background of memory.

who corn s out for baseball
manager and who sticks is learning a lesson
which, whether or not it wins that honor for him,
should win some honors in after life.
He will learn that his plugging on the diamond,
his efforts four years hence to get the upper hand
on his first job, and after that his striving to climb
into the managerial and executive class are all
part of the same game.
Now,just as ten years from now, he will have
to do many things that are hard, many things that
are unpleasant. The more willing he is, the more
work will other men put upon him. But by that
he grows.
The rewards after college are given on about the
same basis as now. Theygo to the man who besides
doing his main job well,still has the time to reach
out after other work and the spirit that masters it.
Here is where this comes home to you. Don't
be content with standing high in the classroom.
Support your college activities and go after some
campus honors too. This broadening of your
interests will become a habit that in .after life will
prove a mighty big help.

The attention of English and American lacrosse enthusiasts
will be centered upon Homewood Field tomorrow, when the combined lacrosse teams of Oxford and Cambridge, fresh from their recent victories over the championship Lehigh team and the Penn
State stickmen, will meet the powerful twelve representing Johns
Hopkins University. Intense interest has been indicated by a large
advance sale of tickets, and lacrosse fans from Washington, Philadelphia, Annapolis and other nearby points will probably be a part
of the record crowd which is expected to be on hand when the referee's whistle announces the commencement of hostilities.

HOPKINS DISTINGUISHED
SCIENTISTS

FOUNDED 1897.

Dr. Ira Remsen was born in
New York City, February 10, 1846.
He received the degree of A. B. in
1865 from the College of the City
of New York. This was followed
by an M. D. at Columbia in '67.
Dr. Remsen later received degrees
of LL. D. at a number of the lead-.
ing universities of North America,
including Yale, Harvard, Toronto,
Princeton, etc. From 1872 to 1876
he was professor at Williams College. From that date until 1913
Dr. Remsen was Professor of
Chemistry at Johns Hopkins. In
1901 he was elected President of
the University and he held that office until his resignation in 1913.
He belonged to practically all the
foremost chemical and scientific societies in this country and abroad,
and has written a number of books
which have added greatly to the
literature upon chemistry. Among
them are "The Principles of Theoretical Chemistry," "The Elements
of Chemistry," "Inorganic Chemistry," and "Chemical Experiments." These books had a vast
influence in the study of the science

WE HAVE WITH US
Tomorrow we will have as our guests a group of selected athletes, representing the two oldest universities in the world.
Most of them are obtaining their first impression of America on
this trip. Thus far, they have invaded the lacrosse field of three universities and have come away with the victor's end of the spoils. We
have reason to believe that things will not go so easily with them out
at Homewood Field tomorrow. The game should be hotly contested throughout and it is therefore essential that both rooters and
players make an especial effort to display good sportsmanship.
The fact that an ex-Hopkins student and player is among the
visitors should serve as an incentive to us to "do him proud".
This international contest, more than all of the other games
combined, will carry with it a great amount of advertising and comment concerning Johns Hopkins.
We can afford to do nothing else than put our best foot forward.
Let's show the visitors from the old world what clean winners—or
what good losers we are.

WANTED
The cheering at the games last Saturday, although good, lacked
the force of supervised effort. The scattered groups of rooters were
enthusiastic and generous with their applause, but the result was
weak and would have been far more pleasing had their efforts been
concentrated.
Through the endeavors of the Sigma Chi Beta Honorary Society, last year, spring sport cheer-leaders were provided. Their
services, with that of the band, served to produce a much smootherrunning rooting section.
Inasmuch as our collection of yell-directors will be sadly depleted by the opening of next term, these spring games seem to offer
an excellent opportunity for the schooling of the new aspirants in
the art of writhing and twisting.
The position of Head Cheer Leader is one offering splendid occasions for an injection of personality. While at first consideration
the office may not appear as exalted a one as that of fullback on
the
football team or star, twirler on the nine, it should be
remembered
that it can be made what its holder wills.
Cheer Leader Mike Curley will be remembered long after
most
of the "star twirlers" of his institution have faded into the
background of memory.

He will learn that his plugging on the diamond,

Here is where this comes home to you. Don't

Support your college activities and go after some

interests will become a habit that in .after life will
